Graphical abstract This review highlights the current and future development of light-driven supercapacitors, focusing on material selection, device design, efficiency, and challenges, while suggesting strategies for improving performance and scalability for industrial and commercial applications. Photo-assisted energy harvesting plays a crucial role in present research and future scenario in the field of technology advancements towards efficient energy utilization. Modern world sees an opportunity in developing such technologies which are self-powered, self-driven and self-healing that can be utilized in the fields including portable, wearable electronics, internet of things (IOT) devices, electric vehicles, space applications, renewable energy systems, and smart grid applications. The present review gives an insight to the aspects in the present and future developmental goals in the field of light driven supercapacitors (LDS). Such systems comprise of active components viz. layer material selection in the solar cell and supercapacitors. A comprehensive study to achieve high absorption, power/energy density and efficient storage of absorbed energy has been discussed. The major factors for device design and mechanism adopted for efficient photo conversion and their subsequent storage as LDS depends on efficient light intensity source, surface area, optimization of the structure of electrodes, electrode selection, charge separation efficiency etc. A comprehensive analysis of the previously developed LDS with their optimized parameters has been presented. Various challenges viz. material selection, compatibility of layers, lower photovoltaic conversion and increased resistivity on integrating the energy conversion and storage module has also been discussed. In order to achieve high-performance LDS and to enhance their practicality various steps are suggested for the future development of LDS at industry and commercial scale. Keywords Supercapacitors Photocapacitance Energy storage Renewable energy 1 Introduction Supercapacitors (SCs) have advanced significantly in the last several years due to the increased need for efficient and sustainable energy storage solutions. These devices offer rapid discharge-charge capabilities, high power density, and exceptional cycle life, making them promising component for various applications ranges from portable devices to renewable energy systems and electric vehicles [1–3]. However, despite these advantages, conventional SCs still face challenges related to energy density and storage capacity. To cope these limitations and utilized SCs with full potential, researchers have been exploring innovative approaches, one of which is the integration of light-driven mechanisms. LDS, also known as photocapacitors, leverage the concept of light absorption and energy conversion to enhance their energy storage capabilities. By harnessing light energy and efficiently storing it in the form of charge, these advanced SCs have the potential to revolutionize the energy storage landscape and pave the way for sustainable and eco-friendly technologies [4]. The urgent need for clean energy solutions and the transition towards a low-carbon future have spurred the quest for highly efficient energy storage devices. While conventional batteries have made significant progress, they still suffer from limitations such as slow charging rates, limited cycle life, and environmental concerns related to their chemical composition. SCs have emerged as a promising alternative to address these challenges, as they offer fast charge-discharge rates and can tolerate a high number of charge cycles [5]. However, their energy density falls short compared to batteries, limiting their application in scenarios requiring extended energy storage. To bridge this energy density gap and unlock the true potential of SCs, researchers have turned to light-driven solutions (LDS). The concept of LDS presents an exciting opportunity to enhance energy storage beyond the limits of traditional SCs. By incorporating light-responsive materials and utilizing photoconversion processes, LDS have the potential to enhance energy storage while maintaining the rapid charge-discharge properties that make SCs attractive thereby harnessing the potential to store energy more efficiently, unlocking new possibilities for energy storage and utilization [6]. LDS leverage the concept of light absorption and energy conversion to enhance their energy storage capabilities. These devices harness light energy to promote charge separation and storage, thus increasing their energy density. Photocapacitance is the key phenomenon that enables LDS, in which the electric double layer capacitance is modified through light-induced charge carriers. This enables the efficient storage of energy in the form of charges, leading to enhanced performance compared to traditional SCs [7,8]. Advancements in materials and technologies play a crucial role in the development of efficient LDS. Researchers have explored a wide range of materials, including nanomaterials, conductive polymers and metal oxides. Nanostructured materials have shown significant potential in improving light absorption and charge storage. For instance, semiconductor (SCN) nanocrystals such as quantum dots have been incorporated into SC electrodes to enhance light absorption and charge transfer processes [9]. Also, conductive polymers have been used widely due to their tuneable characteristics and compatibility with light-driven mechanisms [10]. To optimize the energy harvesting and storage capabilities of LDS, researchers have explored the integration of photovoltaic systems with SCs. This integration allows the simultaneous capture and conversion of light energy into electricity and its storage in SCs. Additionally, the article will delve into various real-world applications where LDS can make a significant impact. 2 Components in LDS 2.1 Solar cell Solar cell devices (SCD) are among the most promising renewable energy sources because of their constant supply, quantity, and environmental friendliness. The majority of SCD are constructed using their photosensitisation procedures. Solar cells utilize semiconductor materials to convert sunlight directly into electricity. The most common material is silicon, available in various forms like crystalline (monocrystalline and polycrystalline) and amorphous. Crystalline silicon offers high efficiency but can be expensive, while amorphous silicon is cheaper but less efficient. Other promising materials include thin-film technologies like cadmium telluride and copper indium gallium selenide, known for their flexibility and potential for lower manufacturing costs. Emerging technologies like perovskite solar cells demonstrate high efficiency and low production costs, showing significant potential for future advancements in solar energy [16–18]. Among them, solar cell based on Si technologies is widely used in industry because of their excellent environmental stability and photoconversion efficiency. Thin-film technology has emerged as an innovative approach to developing solar cell devices (SCD) due to the high costs and complex processes involved in manufacturing silicon solar cells. Similarly, dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) offer a promising alternative to traditional silicon-based SCDs. DSSCs are cost-effective, easy to produce, and boast high light conversion efficiency. Their photoconversion efficiency depends on the interaction between key components: the photoanode (PA), counter electrode (CE), dye material, and electrolyte. However, the variety of material used for the PA and its structure are those primarily determine the solar cell's fill factor, open-circuit voltage, photogenerated current density, and light absorption. While DSSCs show an efficiency of 12.3% in real-time applications, their highest theoretical efficiency is anticipated to be 32% [19,20]. The work function, edges of conduction band, and maximum carrier mobility of ZnO and TiO2 have all been investigated extensively as PA materials. But since ZnO corrodes easily in acidic environments and degrades easily in dye aggregation, its use is constrained [21]. In order for DSSCs to function, light must first cause the dye sensitizer to photogenerate an electron, which is then expelled into the SCN's conduction band (Fig. 1 a). The photogenerated electron exits the device via CE. The gadget transforms into a photovoltaic energy conversion system when an external load is applied in bright light, and it is stabilised by electron regeneration. However, the unfavourable recombination of electrolyte (dye/redox) prior to attaching to an external load compromises the device's overall efficiency [22]. In the last three decades, as previously mentioned DSSCs have been regarded as solar cells having high efficiency (photo conversion) and low-cost. On the other hand, the fabrication of SCD with high efficiency has been the subject of much study. Because of its innovative optoelectronic outputs, solar cell technologies utilizing quantum dot (QD) have been in the vanguard. The variable bandgap, broad excitation spectrum, high extinction coefficient, multiple exciton production, and exceptional photostability are among the size-dependent properties of QD materials. However, research is being done to increase the efficiency of quantum dot sensitized solar cells (QDSSCs), which is now just 16.6%. The primary emphasis of recent research has been on creating environmentally friendly strategies for the preparation of QD in order to decrease the generation of harmful waste and to increase the significance of research on renewable energy [25]. QDSSCs work in a manner similar to DSSCs (Fig. 1b), in which electron-hole pairs are produced in the presence of light. By creating a hole in the QD's VB, the produced electron travels to the QD's conduction band and subsequently to the wide bandgap SCN's CB. After that, across the SCN connected to the PA, the electron travels in the direction of the conducting transparent substrate. The electron then passes across the circuit (external) and is held in the CE. The solar cell efficiency is determined by the voltage that is generated during this process [23]. The voltage generated is the difference between the electrolyte's redox potential and the quasi-Fermi level of the PA's electron [26]. Similar to QDSSCs, perovskite serves as the photosensitiser in third-generation, newly developed photovoltaic devices called perovskite solar cells. They are the top options among the developing photovoltaics due to their bandgap tunability, high absorption coefficient, long diffusion length, extensive material availability, cheap processing costs, and ability to surpass the Shockley-Queisser limit. The efficiency of perovskite devices has approached that of silicon devices that are commercialised. In QDSSCs, perovskites often function as photosensitisers rather than quantum dots. The most popular perovskite is MAPbI3 [27], in which PEDOT:PSS, P3HT, and spiro-OMeTAD function as hole transport layers while materials like SnO2 and TiO2 are often utilised as the electron transport layer [28,29]. Tandem devices have been used recently to increase the solar devices' efficiency. Emerging tandem devices with tandem efficiencies that have already surpassed single-junction silicon SCD are called perovskite silicon tandem devices (Fig. 1c) [24]. Unlike other solar cell technologies, organic photovoltaics operate in a unique way. In the presence of light, free charge carriers like electrons and holes are produced. The two distinct nanostructures found in the layer (active) such as electron donor and acceptor layer that will be responsible for the dissociation of the pair (electron-hole). High electron affinity exists in the acceptor layer and high ionisation potential exists in the donor layer. An electron is moved from the donor material's HOMO to its LUMO and the bandgap energy of the accepter material is less compared to donor material. With an empirical limit of 0.6 eV smaller than the absorber's bandgap, the output voltage is the consequence of difference in energies between LUMO and HOMO (Fig. 1d) [30,31]. 2.2 Supercapacitors LDS also include an energy storage component. In many electrical gadgets, rechargeable batteries are the energy storage component of interest. For energy storage applications, capacitors and supercapacitors have gained significant attention. Supercapacitors offer exceptionally high power density and capacitances several orders of magnitude greater than those of traditional capacitors. However, their energy density is lower compared to batteries. Despite this, SCs present two major advantages: rapid charging capability and excellent cycling performance. The area of LDS may greatly benefit from these new characteristics. Basically, depending on how they store charge, SCs are categorised as three-electric double-layer capacitors (EDLC) [32], pseudocapacitors [33], and hybrid supercapacitors (HSCs) [34,36]. In EDLCs, the mechanism charge storage is achieved by coulombic absorption of charge at the interface of electrolyte-electrode. In contrast, redox processes are responsible for the mechanism of charge storage in pseudocapacitors. For HSCs, both the pseudo mechanism and the EDLC are used. Supercapacitors utilize a variety of materials for their electrodes, each contributing to specific energy storage mechanisms such as ruthenium oxide, manganese oxide, nickel oxide, activated carbon, carbon nanotubes, graphene, polyaniline, and polypyrrole, etc. [37–39]. The choice of electrode material significantly influences the supercapacitor's energy density, power density, and overall performance [40,41]. 2.2.1 Types of SCs based on working mechanism As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the capacitance of a traditional dielectric SCs is basically dependent on the distance between the two electrodes. The interfacial area of EDLC is primarily responsible for charge storage. The stable electrochemically active electrode material experiences ions adsorption reversibly from the electrolyte, which results in the electrostatic storage of charge. The EDL will be formed when electric polarisation observe at the interface of electrolyte-electrode [42]. The double layer stored charge exclusively, and it does not penetrate the anode or cathode electrode. In this case, the dissociation of surface, adsorption on electrode, and defects arises in the material of electrode all contribute to the surface charge generation [44]. The width of the EDL, which is 5–10 Å for electrolytes with high concentration, depends on the ionic size and the utilized electrolyte [45]. Ion-permeable membranes are used to separate the two electrodes in electrolyte in SCs made of electrodes affixed over current collectors (i.e. metallic) [46]. The electrode separation length has an impact on capacitance in conventional capacitors. As opposed to this, the capacitance of EDLC is determined by the EDL that forms between the electrode and electrolyte contact. There will always be a difference between the ion-permeable membrane and EDL width. An additional kind of SCs is a pseudocapacitor, which functions similarly to a battery and SCs. In pseudocapacitors, the process of storing charge is a surface phenomenon (Fig. 2b). Pseudocapacitors operate much as batteries do in terms of storing capacity. Transition metal oxides (MO) and conducting polymers (CPS) are examples of materials that possess behaviour with pseudocapacitive nature [47]. In CPS, the pi-conjugated chain involved in the redox reaction during the electrochemical processes (doping/de-doping) which serves as the energy storage mechanism. Transition metals may store charge by a variety of mechanisms, such as deposition under-potential, alkali metal cations, rapid redox processes brought on by protons intercalating, and intercalation mechanisms [48]. Positive potential in relation to the Nernst potential is the sole condition under which deposition takes place. The oxidised species either absorbed electrochemically on the species (reduced) or in the surrounding of the species through a faradaic route, whereas the species (i.e. converted reduced) are absorbed electrochemically on the exterior of the oxidised species in the case of redox pseudocapacitor [49]. Materials that function according to the aforementioned mechanism include RuO2 and MnO2 [50]. The primary benefit of solid-state diffusion-based pseudocapacitors is their capacity to store more charge in a short amount of time since ion intercalation towards redox-active electrode materials takes place in these devices without requiring any changes in phase (crystallographic). In a material with pseudocapacitive nature the intercalation is dependent on the crystallinity of the materials used in electrode, regardless of capacitance. Though they have a lower electrical conductivity and stability, transition MO offers a larger capacitance theoretically than CPS. They also trade off energy density for power density [51]. The working principle of Hybrid supercapacitor is based on the integration of two different types of energy storage mechanisms: electrostatic and faradaic as shown in Fig. 2(c). Their mixture improves the constraints of the specific pseudocapacitive and EDLC material electrodes. The restrictions in the EDLC are not evident in the pseudocapacitors, and vice versa. Compared to a symmetric supercapacitor (SSCs), a HSCs with two distinct electrodes has better electrochemical activity and a greater specific capacitance [52,53]. The disproportion in the rate of discharge/charge among the electrodes, however, is a significant problem with hybrid capacitors because of the disparity in their energy storage mechanisms [35]. The maximum energy that the intercalation electrode may use will be limited by this storage imbalance, which will have an impact on the system's overall efficiency. By using a large intercalation pseudocapacitive as the material in anode, this imbalance is corrected. With excellent cycle stability, hybrid capacitors provide a better power and energy density than EDLC. SCs are specified as symmetric, [54] asymmetric, [55] and composite hybrids [56] based on active materials used and their electrode configuration. The densities such as power and energy of batteries and SCs are determined by distinct methods, with the former storing charge electrochemically. SCs store energy using a faradaic electrochemical mechanism or electrostatically, as stated before. In comparison to traditional capacitors, they achieve high capacitance by using extremely thin dielectric space and high surface area electrode materials. In batteries, redox processes with diffusion control are the mechanism for charge storage [49]. The charge storage process of SCs achieves storage through electrolyte ions adsorption on the electrode’s surface, avoiding the requirement for redox reactions [56]. SCs have a low energy density and quick discharge/charge speeds in a matter of seconds or minutes when compared to batteries. In addition to being safe, SCs provide high power density, extended cycle life, high efficiency, and great operational stability. SCs, on the other hand, vary primarily from batteries in that their voltage response falls during current discharge and rises linearly during constant current charging [57]. 2.2.2 Types of SCs based on design geometry SCs may be divided into five categories according to their design geometry: 3D in-plane, 3D stacked, 2D in-plane, 2D stacked, and 1D SCs. 1D SCs have a micrometre diameter and a millimetre length. They are made of fibre, wire, or yarn. One of the primary benefits of 1D SCs is their greater mechanical flexibility in comparison to other topologies, as well as their ease of integration into compact places [58]. Under the 2D stacked design, a bottom-top current collector is covered by vertical stacks of the anode, cathode separator, and electrolyte. In 2D in-plane SCs, on the other hand, the design is the opposite of 2D stacked. Anode and cathode electrodes are placed parallel to one another by micrometer-sized interspaces during the interdigital method of construction [59]. The electrolyte, electrodes, and current collector are combined in conformal stacked layers on a substrate that is vertically aligned in three dimensions, forming the 3D stacked geometry. In a stacked structure, ions migrate vertically through the width, while in an in-plane arrangement, they move parallel between the electrodes separated in microscale. Investigation on 3D stacked topologies is still in its early stages, however both 2D and 3D in-plane SCs have been thoroughly studied (Fig. 3 ) [60,61]. The electrolyte and electrode interface are equivalent to other topologies because the topologies of 3D electrode increase the concentration of loading mass, enhance kinetics of mass transport, and lower the distance (ionic diffusion). The film-like structure of layer-by-layer integrated electrodes makes them brittle, while the 3D architecture has a longer cycle life and stable mechanically. A wide range of templates, such as nanowires, nanowalls, nanosheets, and nanotubes, have been studied to create the 3D topology [62]. Nevertheless, 3D templating has problems with spacing, such as maintaining the appropriate distance between the nanostructures. The active material is deposited in the holes created by etching in order to build 3D SCs, which are extensively used. The primary difference between this topology and layer-by-layer production is how the electrode material is buried in the hollow. Commonly lithography, inkjet printing, etching of plasma, and 3D printing are used to create 3D SCs [61,63]. Among them, additive manufacturing also referred to as successful prototyping is produced by 3D printing. After a 3D model is created using software, computer programming is used to create sliced layers of 2D items, which are then printed into a 3D structure. The specifics of a few factors that are important in 3D printing are accessible elsewhere and are beyond the purview of this review article [64,65]. 2.2.3 Types of SCs based on different function Micro-supercapacitors: Miniaturized energy devices are necessary due to the fast fabrication of devices that utilized wearable electronic for various applications such as sensors (self-powered), biomedical and wearable gadgets (self-monitoring) [66]. The poor cycle stability and low power density of conventional electrochemical batteries restrict their use in these applications. Given the limitations of batteries, SCs provide a superior option for extended periods of use because of their high cycle stability [67]. Miniaturized micro- SCs are presently being employed extensively in place of conventional thin-film SCs, which are still in their infancy when it comes to meeting the needs of wearable electronics. Typically, the thickness of the electrode significantly reduces power density and impedes rapid ion movement in SCs. Micro- SCs, which produce increased ion transport by carefully separating microelectrode fingers in the micrometer range, have thus arisen as a solution to these problems. Nonetheless, they operate via comparable methods as traditional SCs [68]. Ultimately, this kind of gadget can be effortlessly merged with other working electrical devices since the separation of the electrode fingers removes the chance of a short circuit. Micro SCs may be created using a variety of manufacturing techniques, including as lithography, direct inkjet printing, laser writing, plasma etching, and the active electrode materials deposition on a pattern substrate [69]. Sun et al. employed a highly concentrated graphene oxide (GO) ink (20 mg mL−1) for extrusion printing [69]. They fabricated interdigitated microelectrodes with an electrode width and spacing of approximately 600 and 500 µm, respectively. Subsequently, the printed GO pattern was chemically reduced, and an electrolyte coating was applied (Fig. 4 ). Electrochromic supercapacitors: A material that displays a colour shift during oxidation and redox processes engaged in the electrochemical method is said to have electrochromism [70]. The fields of optoelectronics and energy storage devices like SCs and batteries both heavily rely on these kinds of materials. The devices listed above are often made utilizing CPS and transition MO, which exhibit an effect that is electrochromic [71]. In the case of SCs, the mechanism of EDL or a pseudocapacitive is used for charge storage. The transference of charge and colour changes in the materials happen during the faradaic reaction. The use of materials that are electrochromic in SC provides a clear representation of the charge level since the materials exhibit electrochromism throughout ejection or injection of charge. Because the electrochromic SC makes variations in an expectable way and makes it easy to understand the device's energy use and current energy level, electrochromic devices are intelligent gadgets [72]. Self-healing supercapacitors: In real-world applications, folding, mechanical bending, compressing, or the discharge/charge method may cause materials of electrode to shatter. The device's safety and electrochemical performance are impacted by this breakdown of the electrode materials. Therefore, a SC that performs both improved capacitance and maintains electrochemical parameters even in the event of mechanical damage is suitable. SCs that can heal themselves are a leading solution to these problems. Plants and animals recover themselves after suffering injuries [73]. The same mechanism, which is carried out by either microencapsulation or molecular interdiffusion, is mirrored in SCs [74]. The process of creating self-healing SCs often involves incorporating appropriate self-healing materials into the device while maintaining its electrochemical and structural integrity. Usually, a self-healing polymer substrate is used to manufacture the SC. In the event of any fractures, the broken surface congregates and mends itself. The primary issue with materials that are self-healing is that most of them negatively impact the SC's characteristics, making it difficult to optimize a suitable material. Prior to building the device, all of these parameters must be tuned since certain polymers would only polymerize at optimum conditions, which might have an impact on the SC's performance [75]. Other SCs are also available; they are covered in other places and are not included in this review article. Examples of these other kinds of SCs include electrochemical flow SCs, AC filtering SCs, and flexible SCs [76–78]. 2.3 Charging methods There are several charging methods for SCs, each tailored to optimize the charging process based on the characteristics of the specific SC and its intended application. The concept of self-charging SCs involves the integration of energy harvesting mechanisms directly into the SC device, allowing it to recharge using ambient energy sources. Table 1 distinguishes the methods adopted to charge the SC via conventional and self-charging approaches. Self-charging methods for SCs are preferred for several reasons, primarily due to their potential to enhance the usability and practicality of SCs in various applications [89–93]. Out of all the self-charging methods based SCs, researchers are moving towards LDS due to the potential to combine energy storage capabilities with light-induced charge separation, allowing for enhanced energy storage and unique applications. LDS can leverage light-induced reactions (redox) at the electrolyte- electrode interface (pseudocapacitance) to store additional charge, leading to higher energy density compared to conventional SCs [94]. LDS can directly convert and store solar energy, providing a means of energy storage from renewable sources like sunlight [95]. The unique charge separation mechanism in LDS can enable rapid charge and discharge rates, offering quick energy transfer [96]. LDS often employ environmentally friendly and sustainable materials as photoactive components, reducing the reliance on toxic or rare elements [97]. Researchers explore integrating LDS with other energy storage technologies like batteries or solar cells, to create hybrid energy storage systems, optimizing overall performance [98]. LDS are in the early phases of development, and efforts to improve their efficiency, stability, and performance are ongoing. Despite these challenges, research in this area shows immense potential to drive advancements in energy storage technologies and promote a sustainable energy future. 3 Light-driven supercapacitors LDS, also known as light-assisted SCs or photoelectrochemical SCs are energy storage device that associates the principles of SCs with photoelectrochemical processes. The detailed mechanism for LDS is shown in Fig. 6 . These devices utilize light-absorbing materials to generate photoelectrons, which enhance the capacity to storage of charge in the SCs. LDS have the capability to offer both high power density and energy density, making them advanced for various storage of energy and conversion uses. It works on the principle of photoelectrochemical processes that involve light-induced redox reactions at the electrode surfaces, where energy of light is used to promote transference of electron between the electrode and electrolyte, generating additional charge carriers and providing pseudocapacitive behaviour [99,100]. Pseudocapacitive behavior in LDS enhances the charge storage mechanism by introducing faradaic reactions at the electrode-electrolyte interface. These reactions involve the transfer of electrons between the electrode and electroactive species in the electrolyte. Light energy triggers the generation of electron-hole pairs, providing the necessary driving force for these redox reactions. The generated carriers participate in fast and reversible redox processes, such as the oxidation and reduction of transition metal oxides or conducting polymers on the electrode surface. This mechanism, in addition to the traditional double-layer capacitance, significantly increases the overall charge storage capacity of the device [101]. The active electrode materials are typically sensitized with photoactive components, such as SCNs or photoactive molecules. When these materials are exposed to light, they undergo photoexcitation, leading to the generation of hole-electron pairs. The created electrons and holes can travel to the electrode-electrolyte interface, leading to charge separation [102]. The charge separation induced by photoexcitation contributes to pseudocapacitance, which is the additional charge storage mechanism beyond the double-layer capacitance of traditional SCs. Pseudocapacitance arises from faradaic reactions, where reactions (redox) involving transference of charge occur at the surfaces of electrode. These results in additional charge storage compared to capacitance obtained through pure double-layer [103]. The combination of pseudocapacitance and double-layer capacitance in LDS enables higher energy storage capacities than conventional SCs. The rapid charge/discharge characteristics of the double-layer capacitance and the additional storage of charge from pseudocapacitance make LDS suitable for high-power and high-energy applications [104]. Pseudocapacitive behavior significantly enhances the performance of LDS by increasing both energy density and power density. The fast and reversible faradaic reactions associated with pseudocapacitance contribute substantially to overall charge storage, leading to higher energy density. Moreover, these rapid reactions enable fast charge and discharge cycles, resulting in high power output. This synergistic effect between light-induced charge separation and pseudocapacitance offers the potential for LDS to achieve superior performance compared to traditional supercapacitors, making them promising candidates for various energy storage applications [105]. 3.1 Charging and discharging phenomenon During the charging process of an LDS, light energy is harvested and converted into electrical energy, which is stored as charge on the electrodes. The LDS typically consists of SCN materials that can absorb photons and generate electron-hole pairs through the photoelectric effect. When light (photons) strikes the SCN electrode of the LDS, it excites electrons in the SCN, creating electron-hole pairs. The electron-hole pairs get separated at the interface between the SCN and the electrolyte, with electrons moving towards one electrode (e.g., the negative electrode or anode) and holes moving toward the opposite electrode (e.g., the positive electrode or cathode). As with conventional SCs, the charge separation creates an electrostatic double layer at each electrode-electrolyte interface, resulting in the accumulation of electrical charge. The flow of electrons and holes between the two electrodes generates a light-induced current, which is used to charge the SC. For charging under short circuit condition, the capacitor has to be exposed to the desired light irradiation (preferably 100 mW cm−2). At the photoelectrode, the light irradiation generates anodic photocurrent, which is the flow of electrons from the photoelectrode to the CE via the external circuit. The initial photocurrent quickly drops, indicating an exponential decay that is comparable to double-layer capacitors operating in constant-voltage mode while they are being charged. When the circuit is open, the photoelectrode generates a negative photovoltaic potential at a certain potential in relation to the CE. The photovoltaic system functions as an independent power source for the self-charging reaction. To halt the flow of electrons after continuous photocharging, the cell may be open-circuited. Through the monitoring of the cell voltage as a function of time, the discharge operation would subject the capacitor put in the dark to a controlled constant-current discharge. To initiate the discharging process, the LDS is connected to an external circuit, completing the circuit loop [107]. When the circuit is closed, the electrons and holes recombine, and this result in the release of stored electrical energy in the form of a flow of electrons through the external circuit. As the LDS discharges, its voltage across the terminals decreases gradually until it reaches a minimum value, depending on the energy stored and the load connected. The results obtained show that reversible charging and discharging may occur in a cell that contains just complete electrode components, i.e., AC particles immobilized on both the photo- and CE. The CE side is where the negative charge (electron storage) is shown by the charged photoelectrode showing at a positive voltage against it. Cell resistance caused an initial IR drop that was followed by a continuous decline in cell voltage over time upon discharge. The double-layer capacitor, whose capacitance value is equal to the reciprocal of the slope, has this continuous voltage drop as one of its characteristics, I Δ t Δ V , where I and t represent current and discharging time, respectively. Thus, the charge accumulation at the electrode surfaces results in the storage of electrical energy in the form of stored charge. Unlike batteries, which involve chemical reactions, the charging process in a LDS is primarily based on physical adsorption and desorption of ions on the electrode surfaces, leading to rapid charging and discharging capabilities. The LDS may release its stored charge as electrical energy to power an external circuit when it is attached to one. Through the external circuit, electrons go from one electrode to the other, while ions from the electrolyte migrate to balance the charge. It is important to note that the charging and discharging of LDS are dependent on the availability of light energy. As long as light is present and incident on the SCN electrodes, the LDS can continue to charge and discharge. 3.2 Factors responsible for energy conversion in LDS Numerous parameters, such as the SCN material's bandgap, the intensity and wavelength of incoming light, the electrodes' surface area and structure, and the electrolyte's composition, all affect how efficiently light is absorbed and converted into energy in LDS [108–110]. Some of the key factors responsible for energy conversion in an LDS include: Photoactive materials: The photoactive material in an LDS is responsible for absorbing light energy and converting it into electrical energy. It typically consists of a semiconductor material, such as titanium dioxide (TiO2) or zinc oxide (ZnO), that can absorb photons from the incident light. When a photon is absorbed, it excites an electron in the semiconductor, creating an electron-hole pair. The excited electron can then be transported to the electrode, while the hole is transported to the counter-electrode, generating a potential difference that can be used to store energy in the supercapacitor [111]. Electrode materials: The electrode materials in LDS play a crucial role in efficiently collecting and storing the electrical charges generated by the photoactive material. They must possess high electrical conductivity to facilitate the rapid movement of electrons and holes, and exhibit good electrochemical activity to enable reversible redox reactions [112]. Additionally, the electrodes should be compatible with both the photoactive material and the electrolyte to ensure stable and efficient operation of the device. Electrolyte selection: The electrolyte in LDS is the crucial component that facilitates the movement of ions between the electrodes during charging and discharging processes. Its properties significantly impact the device's performance, stability, and energy density. An ideal electrolyte should possess high ionic conductivity to enable rapid charge transfer, a wide electrochemical stability window to allow for higher operating voltages, and chemical and electrochemical stability to prevent degradation and ensure long-term operation. Furthermore, it must be compatible with both the electrode materials and the photoactive material to avoid side reactions or corrosion. Various types of electrolytes, including aqueous, organic, ionic liquids, and solid-state electrolytes, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, have been investigated for use in light-dependent supercapacitors. Ongoing research focuses on developing novel electrolytes with improved properties, such as higher ionic conductivity, wider electrochemical stability, and better compatibility with electrode materials, to further enhance the performance and practical applications of these devices [113]. Device architecture: The device architecture of a light-dependent supercapacitor plays a crucial role in optimizing its performance. It involves careful consideration of factors such as light absorption, charge transport, and overall device stability. An ideal architecture maximizes light absorption by the photoactive material, ensuring efficient conversion of light energy into electrical energy. This often involves optimizing the thickness and surface area of the photoactive layer, as well as incorporating light-trapping structures to enhance light absorption. Additionally, the architecture should facilitate efficient charge transport between the photoactive material, the electrodes, and the electrolyte. This can involve minimizing charge recombination pathways and optimizing the interface between different components. Furthermore, the device architecture should be designed to ensure mechanical stability and prevent degradation over time. This may involve using suitable encapsulation materials and robust fabrication techniques. By carefully considering these factors, researchers can develop light-dependent supercapacitors with optimized performance and long-term stability [114]. External factors: External factors, such as light intensity and spectrum, as well as temperature, can significantly influence the energy conversion efficiency and overall performance of LDS. The intensity and spectral distribution of the incident light directly affect the amount of energy absorbed by the photoactive material. Higher light intensity generally leads to increased photocurrent generation, while the spectral distribution should ideally match the absorption band of the photoactive material for optimal energy conversion. Temperature can also play a crucial role, affecting charge carrier mobility, reaction kinetics, and device stability. Operating the device at an optimal temperature can enhance its performance and longevity. Understanding and controlling these external factors are essential for optimizing the design and operation of light-dependent supercapacitors and maximizing their practical applications. 3.3 Working principles of LDS A photo-assisted rechargeable storage of energy device harvests, converts, and stores solar energy, among other roles or tasks. Therefore, such a gadget is composed of two parts: One component is in charge of gathering and converting sunlight [115]. Energy storage is handled by another component. Many SCs as well as batteries have been produced, with those containing solar cells, among other electrochemical energy storage technologies. These devices were first only put together by joining two devices together through a wire of metal. Consequently, such gadgets aren't really photo-assisted. In order to create various photoelectrodes, SCN nanostructures have recently been progressively added to these devices. Solar energy storage and conversion have been accomplished in these lone devices. Following the interaction of light, an energy storage device may use light energy to accelerate charging and improve energy density. There are also light-assisted gadgets that can charge themselves when exposed to ambient light, doing away with the need for additional power sources. This functionality is especially helpful for distant locations with limited access to traditional charging methods and low-power apps. In particular, adding light to metal batteries enhances the effectiveness of the applied catalyst while simultaneously quickening the cell's reaction kinetics [116,117]. The use of photoelectrochemical processes, for instance, expedited or accelerated several reactions (such as the oxygen evolution and reduction reactions), which ultimately improved reaction kinetics, boosted efficiency, and improved battery performance overall. The operating concepts of two common electrochemical devices, the battery and the SC, are discussed before the specifics of these photo-assisted storage of energy devices are presented. An energy-storage device with a structure similar to a battery is the SC. Its components are a negative electrode submerged in an electrolyte and a positive electrode. An ion-permeable electron-insulating membrane is placed between two electrodes. A (porous) electrode surface experiences electrochemical reactions or these desorption/adsorption of ions throughout the energy storage method. Specifically, transference of charge occurs at the interface between the electrolyte and electrode [118]. Electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudo capacitors (PCs) are two categories into which SCs may be classified based on how they store energy. The following methods provide a comprehensive framework for this evaluation. 3.4.1 Photon energy conversion efficiency Photon energy conversion efficiency represents the ability of a system, such as LDS, to convert incident photons into usable electrical energy or charges. This efficiency is a product of multiple processes, including light absorption, charge generation and separation, and charge collection [126]. It is calculated as the fraction of incident photon energy converted into electrical energy, expressed mathematically as (1) η conversion = η absorption . η charge η absorption refers to the percentage of incident photons absorbed by the photoactive material, while η charge accounts for the efficiency of converting absorbed photons into free charges and collecting them at the electrodes. Techniques such as UV-Vis spectroscopy are used to measure absorption, while external quantum efficiency (EQE) and photoluminescence studies help evaluate charge separation and collection dynamics. High photon energy conversion efficiency requires optimized material properties, minimal recombination losses, and effective charge transport pathways. This metric is crucial for assessing the performance of LDS in harnessing and utilizing solar energy. Absorption efficiency (η absorption) quantifies the fraction of incident light energy absorbed by a material or system [127]. It is a critical parameter in determining the performance of light-dependent devices, such as supercapacitors and solar cells, as it directly influences their ability to harness photon energy. Mathematically, absorption efficiency is expressed as (2) η absorption = P absorbed / P incident where P absorbed is the power absorbed by the material, and P incident is the power of the incident light. Tools such as UV-Vis spectroscopy are commonly used to measure the absorption spectrum and determine the range and magnitude of light absorption. For optimal efficiency, the material's absorption should align with the spectrum of the incident light source, typically solar radiation for many applications. Factors such as material thickness, optical density, and the presence of reflective or scattering layers also affect absorption efficiency. Enhancing η absorption involves using advanced materials like quantum dots, dyes, or nanostructures to increase the interaction between light and the active medium. Charge separation and collection efficiency (η charge) represents the ability of a light-dependent system to effectively separate photogenerated charge carriers and transport them to the respective electrodes for energy conversion [128]. It is a vital factor that determines how efficiently the absorbed photon energy is transformed into usable electrical energy. This efficiency depends on the material's intrinsic properties, such as charge carrier mobility, exciton dissociation efficiency, and the presence of electric fields to drive charge separation. Additionally, minimizing recombination losses—where electrons and holes recombine without contributing to current-is essential for high efficiency. Techniques like external quantum efficiency measurements and time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) are commonly used to evaluate η charge. A high charge separation and collection efficiency requires optimized interfaces between the photoactive material and electrodes, as well as low resistive losses in the transport layers. Enhancements can be achieved through strategies such as introducing energy-level matching layers, improving material crystallinity, and incorporating nanostructured architectures to facilitate charge transport pathways. 3.4.2 Energy storage efficiency Energy storage efficiency (η storage) measures how effectively a system stores the energy it absorbs or converts and later retrieves it for use. It is a key parameter for evaluating the performance of energy storage devices, such as LDS [129]. This efficiency is expressed as the ratio of energy retrieved during discharge to the energy initially stored during charging, typically written as (3) η storage = E stored / E retrieved where E retrieved is the total energy extracted during the discharge process, and E stored is the energy input during charging. This ratio accounts for energy losses that occur due to internal resistance, leakage currents, and other inefficiencies in the storage mechanism. In light-dependent systems, energy storage efficiency is influenced by both the electrochemical properties of the storage medium and the integration with the light-harvesting components. For LDS, the efficiency is determined by the ability to store photogenerated charges in a stable manner and retrieve them without significant losses. Factors like the electrode material, electrolyte properties, and device architecture play a significant role in determining η storage. Materials with high capacitance, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, or metal oxides, are often used to enhance energy storage. To evaluate η storage, several experimental techniques are employed: Galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) is a fundamental technique for evaluating the performance of energy storage devices, including LDS. In this method, a constant current is applied to charge and discharge the device while monitoring the corresponding voltage changes over time. The resulting charge-discharge profiles provide critical insights into the device's energy storage capabilities, including capacitance, energy density, power density, and charge retention efficiency. The specific capacitance (C) is calculated from the discharge curve using the equation. (4) C = I Δ t / Δ V where I is the constant current, Δt is the discharge time, and ΔV is the voltage window. The area under the curve reflects the energy stored during charging and retrieved during discharging, allowing for the determination of energy and power densities. GCD also reveals information about resistive losses and device stability. The voltage drop at the beginning of the discharge curve, known as IR drop, indicates internal resistance. A small IR drop signifies low resistance and high charge transport efficiency, which are essential for maximizing energy storage efficiency. For light-dependent systems, GCD measurements under illumination provide additional insights into photocharging behavior and the ability of the system to store photogenerated charges. Comparing charge-discharge cycles in the presence and absence of light helps assess the integration efficiency between the light-harvesting and storage components. GCD is widely used due to its simplicity, reproducibility, and ability to simulate practical device operation. By analyzing the charge-discharge profiles, researchers can optimize material properties, electrode design, and device architecture to enhance the overall performance of energy storage systems. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) is a widely used electrochemical technique for evaluating the electrochemical performance of energy storage devices, such as supercapacitors and LDS. It provides valuable information about the redox reactions, charge storage capacity, and kinetics of the system under both reversible and non-reversible conditions. During a CV measurement, a potential is swept linearly between two limits while measuring the resulting current. The resulting current-potential curve reveals key characteristics such as capacitance, resistance, and faradaic processes involved in energy storage. In the context of light-dependent supercapacitors, CV is particularly useful for understanding how effectively photogenerated charges are stored and utilized. By performing CV under both dark and illuminated conditions, researchers can assess the contribution of photo-assisted energy storage. The integrated area under the CV curve represents the total charge storage capacity, which is crucial for evaluating the device's energy storage efficiency. Higher areas correspond to greater capacitance and, consequently, improved energy storage capabilities. Additionally, CV helps identify the behavior of the electrode–electrolyte interface, enabling the detection of any pseudocapacitive or faradaic contributions to energy storage. This is essential for understanding the influence of material properties, such as surface area, porosity, and electroactive sites, on overall performance. Moreover, CV can reveal any hysteresis or reversibility losses, which impact the efficiency and longevity of the device. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is a powerful analytical technique used to investigate the electrical properties of energy storage devices, including light-dependent supercapacitors (LDSCs). EIS provides a detailed understanding of the internal resistances, charge transfer dynamics, and diffusion processes within the system. During an EIS measurement, the device is subjected to a small AC perturbation while a DC bias is applied. The resulting impedance spectrum is plotted over a range of frequencies, revealing the frequency-dependent response of the system. In the context of LDSCs, EIS is crucial for identifying key factors that affect energy storage efficiency. The spectrum typically consists of two main regions: a high-frequency region dominated by resistance and a low-frequency region dominated by diffusion and Warburg impedance. By analyzing the Nyquist and Bode plots, researchers can evaluate the various resistances such as electrolyte resistance, charge transfer resistance at the electrode-electrolyte interface, and series resistance. Lower impedance values indicate reduced energy losses and improved device performance. EIS also provides insight into the kinetics of charge storage processes, allowing for the optimization of electrode materials and electrolyte compositions to minimize internal losses. 3.5 Advantages of LDS Enhanced energy storage efficiency: One of the primary advantages of light-driven supercapacitors is their ability to utilize light to enhance energy storage performance [130]. By integrating light-responsive materials, such as photoactive electrodes or photocatalysts, LDS can harness photons to increase their charge storage capacity and boost the conductivity of the electrode materials. This interaction allows the supercapacitor to exhibit higher capacitance, energy density, and power density under light exposure compared to conventional supercapacitors operating in the dark [131,132]. For instance, materials like titanium dioxide (TiO2), graphene, or other photoactive compounds can undergo changes in their electrochemical properties when exposed to light, leading to improved ion transport and more efficient charge storage. This feature makes LDS particularly useful in environments where ambient light is abundant, allowing them to take advantage of external energy sources to boost their performance. Eco-friendly energy enhancement: LDS devices offer a sustainable and environmentally friendly way to enhance energy storage. By leveraging solar or ambient light as a supplemental energy source, LDS systems do not require additional electrical input to improve performance, reducing the need for fossil fuels and other non-renewable energy sources. This feature aligns well with global efforts to reduce carbon footprints and adopt cleaner energy solutions. Additionally, the fact that these supercapacitors are designed to function with renewable energy sources like sunlight makes them ideal for integration into solar-powered systems [133,134]. This synergy with renewable energy technologies positions LDS as an attractive option for the development of greener, more sustainable energy storage solutions. High power output and fast charging: Like conventional supercapacitors, LDS devices are capable of delivering high power outputs due to their low internal resistance and fast charge/discharge rates. The light-induced enhancement further amplifies this capability, allowing them to respond quickly to energy demands. This is particularly useful in applications that require bursts of energy, such as powering sensors, smart devices, or short-term energy needs in renewable energy systems. Because supercapacitors can charge and discharge rapidly without significant energy losses, LDS devices are well-suited for applications that demand quick energy access. When exposed to light, the efficiency of charging can improve, making these devices even more responsive [135]. Long cycle life: Supercapacitors, in general, have a much longer cycle life compared to traditional energy storage devices like batteries. LDS devices inherit this advantage, as they can undergo hundreds of thousands of charge/discharge cycles with minimal degradation [136]. The use of light to enhance performance does not typically introduce significant wear and tear on the materials, meaning that the durability of the supercapacitor is preserved. This long cycle life reduces the need for frequent replacements, making LDS devices cost-effective over the long term. Their durability also makes them ideal for applications where reliability and longevity are important, such as in renewable energy systems, remote sensors, and autonomous devices [137]. 3.6 Disadvantages of LDS Dependence on light availability: One of the significant limitations of light-driven supercapacitors is their dependence on light availability to achieve enhanced performance. In environments with limited or no light, such as indoors, at night, or in shaded areas, LDS devices revert to functioning like traditional supercapacitors, losing their light-driven performance enhancement. This makes their efficiency highly variable depending on environmental conditions. While they can still store and release energy in the dark, their performance will not be as optimal compared to when they are exposed to light. This reliance on external light sources can limit their practical use in certain scenarios or require additional systems, such as hybrid energy sources, to maintain consistent performance [138]. Complexity of material integration: The design and fabrication of LDS systems are more complex than conventional supercapacitors due to the need for light-responsive materials. These materials must be carefully selected and integrated into the device structure to ensure that they can interact effectively with light without compromising the fundamental performance of the supercapacitor. Finding materials that offer both high energy storage capacity and efficient light responsiveness can be challenging. For example, many materials that are effective as electrodes may not have strong photoactive properties, requiring the use of additional layers or coatings [139]. This complexity in material selection and integration can lead to increased manufacturing costs and longer development times, limiting the scalability and commercialization of LDS technologies. Limited energy density compared to batteries: While LDS devices have improved energy density compared to traditional supercapacitors, they still fall short when compared to batteries like lithium-ion [140]. Supercapacitors in general are known for their high power density but low energy density, which means they are more suited for applications that require quick energy bursts rather than long-term energy storage. In applications that demand large amounts of stored energy over extended periods, LDS devices may not be able to compete with batteries, which can store significantly more energy in a smaller volume. This limitation restricts the use of LDS devices in high-energy-demand applications, such as electric vehicles or large-scale renewable energy storage. Potential for material degradation: Certain light-responsive materials used in LDS devices may degrade over time due to prolonged exposure to sunlight, UV radiation, or environmental factors like humidity and temperature fluctuations. For instance, organic photoactive materials or some perovskite-based systems may experience a decrease in performance over time when exposed to environmental stresses. This degradation can limit the lifespan and reliability of LDS devices, especially in outdoor applications where they are continuously exposed to sunlight. Material degradation can reduce the overall efficiency and longevity of the device, requiring periodic maintenance or replacement of components. This adds to the operational costs and can reduce the overall viability of LDS systems in long-term applications [141,142]. Higher manufacturing costs: The integration of light-responsive materials into supercapacitors increases manufacturing complexity, which can drive up costs. The need for specialized materials and fabrication processes, such as the deposition of photoactive coatings or the integration of nanomaterials, makes LDS devices more expensive to produce compared to conventional supercapacitors or even batteries. This higher cost can be a barrier to widespread adoption, especially in cost-sensitive applications. Until economies of scale are achieved or new, more cost-effective materials are developed, the high manufacturing costs may limit the commercial viability of LDS technology. Whereas, dependence on light availability, degradation of photovoltaic materials and thermal management issues are the disadvantages of integrated photo-supercapacitor. Incorporating power electronic converters, such as boost converters and Maximum Power Point Trackers (MPPTs), can improve efficiency but adds complexity and cost to the system. This can be challenging due to the heat generated by both the solar cell and the supercapacitor during operation. Ensuring the long-term reliability and durability of the integrated system under various environmental conditions is critical. Factors like temperature fluctuations, humidity, and mechanical stress can affect the performance of both the solar cell and the supercapacitor. Achieving a balance between performance and cost is essential for widespread adoption. Market competitiveness: To achieve widespread adoption, LDS must demonstrate strong market competitiveness. This necessitates careful consideration of cost-effectiveness, manufacturing scalability, and performance-to-price ratios. The use of expensive materials like noble metals (e.g., platinum, ruthenium) for photocatalysis significantly increases manufacturing costs. Developing cost-effective alternatives, such as earth-abundant materials (e.g., transition metal oxides, sulfides, and nitrides), is crucial for commercial viability. Complex fabrication processes, such as those involving nanostructuring and precise device assembly, can increase production costs. Exploring low-cost, scalable manufacturing techniques, including roll-to-roll processing and 3D printing, is essential for mass production. A comprehensive evaluation of energy density, power density, cycle life, and overall efficiency is necessary to assess the cost-effectiveness of LDS. Optimizing device architecture and materials selection can significantly improve performance-to-price ratios. Large-scale synthesis and purification of high-quality photoactive materials with consistent properties remain a significant challenge. Developing efficient and scalable synthesis methods is crucial for reducing production costs. Integrating LDS into existing systems, such as portable electronics or renewable energy grids, requires careful consideration of compatibility, reliability, and safety. Minimizing the environmental impact of manufacturing processes is crucial for sustainable development. This includes reducing waste generation, minimizing energy consumption, and utilizing eco-friendly materials and solvents. By addressing these challenges and capitalizing on recent advancements in materials science, nanotechnology, and device engineering, researchers can pave the way for the commercialization of high-performance, cost-effective LDS, enabling a sustainable and energy-efficient future. 4 Materials for LDS Materials play a pivotal role in the development and functionality of LDS, innovative devices at the intersection of energy storage and solar energy harvesting. Solid electrolytes are unquestionably safer when used in flexible devices where frequent folding and squeezing might cause liquid to spill. The principle of integrating solar cells with supercapacitors lies in harnessing solar energy to directly charge the supercapacitor. Solar cells convert sunlight into electrical energy, and this generated electricity is then used to charge the supercapacitor. The supercapacitor stores this energy efficiently and can quickly release it on demand, providing a reliable and sustainable power source for various applications. This integration effectively combines the energy harvesting capabilities of solar cells with the high power density and rapid charge-discharge characteristics of supercapacitors. The integration of solar cells with supercapacitors involves a synergistic combination of energy harvesting and storage. Solar cells convert sunlight into electrical energy, while supercapacitors efficiently store and rapidly deliver this energy. This integration leverages the high power density of supercapacitors to buffer the intermittent nature of solar energy, enabling a more reliable and consistent power supply. Key mechanisms include direct electrical connection between the solar cell and supercapacitor, allowing for immediate storage of the generated electricity, and efficient charge transfer facilitated by the high power density of the supercapacitor. This integration enhances the overall efficiency and reliability of solar energy systems, particularly for applications requiring high power bursts or rapid load fluctuations. Integrating solar cells with supercapacitors creates a powerful energy harvesting and storage system, enhancing the utilization of solar energy. Both can be integrated using various combinations such as direct connection, power electronic converters, hybrid systems etc. In direct connection, directly connecting the solar cell's output to the supercapacitor terminals. A diode is crucial to prevent reverse current flow from the supercapacitor back to the solar cell during periods of low or no sunlight. For more efficient charging, a simple charge controller can be added. This regulates the current flow to the supercapacitor, preventing overcharging and extending its lifespan. In power electronic converters boost converters are utilized. These step-up converters increase the voltage output of the solar cell, allowing it to charge the supercapacitor to a higher voltage, improving energy storage capacity. Combining a supercapacitor with a battery creates a hybrid system that leverages the strengths of both. The supercapacitor handles high-power demands and rapid charge/discharge cycles, while the battery provides long-term energy storage. During integration process, the impedance of the solar cell and the supercapacitor should be carefully matched to optimize energy transfer. Efficient heat dissipation is crucial to prevent overheating of the components, especially in high-temperature environments. Incorporate safety mechanisms like overvoltage protection, overcurrent protection, and short-circuit protection to ensure safe operation. On the other hand, redox pairs and photoactive materials have the ability to absorb, transform, and store solar energy. LDS have high operating voltages, prolonged cycle stability, cheap cost, and simplicity of assembly. To sum up, LDS provide a fresh approach to better addressing the expanding need for energy in the years to come. Their arrival provides fresh motivation for the creation of innovative eco-friendly gadgets like solar-powered electric cars that run on rechargeable batteries. If their advantages of wearability, portability, and miniaturization can be further incorporated, they are beneficial for devices (smart electronic) that are portable and renewable. To be clear, before LDS really moves towards commercialization and industrial applications, a great deal of obstacles still needs to be addressed. 7 Future application of LDS LDS hold immense potential for future applications due to their unique ability to directly convert solar energy into electrical energy and store it efficiently. Some key areas where LDS could revolutionize energy storage: Self-powered sensors and IoT devices: Self-powered sensors and IoT devices, enabled by energy harvesting technologies like LDS, revolutionize remote monitoring and data collection. By eliminating the need for battery replacements or external power sources, these devices can operate autonomously in remote locations, enabling applications such as environmental monitoring, precision agriculture, and industrial automation. This not only reduces maintenance costs but also enhances sustainability and expands the reach of IoT networks into previously inaccessible areas. Portable electronics: LDS can revolutionize portable electronics by enabling self-charging devices. Imagine smartphones, wearables, and other gadgets that continuously recharge themselves using ambient light, eliminating the need for frequent charging cycles and extending battery life significantly. This would enhance user experience, reduce reliance on external power sources, and contribute to a more sustainable and convenient lifestyle [256]. Renewable energy grid integration: Integrating LDS into renewable energy grids can significantly enhance grid stability and reliability. By storing excess solar energy during peak generation periods and releasing it during periods of high demand, LDS can effectively smooth out power fluctuations caused by the intermittent nature of renewable sources like solar and wind [257]. This can improve grid stability, reduce reliance on fossil fuels for peak load balancing, and facilitate the wider adoption of renewable energy technologies. Electric vehicles: Electric vehicles (EVs) offer a compelling solution to the challenges of transportation-related pollution and energy dependence. By integrating LDS into EV powertrains, we can significantly enhance their performance and sustainability. LDS can provide rapid bursts of power for acceleration, regenerative braking, and other high-power demands, complementing the primary battery system. This can improve vehicle performance, extend driving range, and reduce reliance on the main battery, thus prolonging its lifespan. Furthermore, by directly utilizing solar energy to recharge the LDS, we can reduce the burden on the grid and minimize the environmental impact of transportation. This integration of LDS into EVs represents a significant step towards a cleaner, more sustainable, and more efficient transportation future [258,259]. Space exploration: LDS offer a compelling solution for powering space missions [260,261]. In the harsh environment of space, where sunlight is abundant but traditional energy sources like batteries have limitations, LDS can provide a reliable and sustainable power source. By directly converting solar energy into electrical energy and storing it efficiently, LDS can power critical components of spacecraft, including communication systems, scientific instruments, and propulsion systems. This can enable longer and more ambitious space missions, such as deep space exploration and the establishment of lunar and Martian bases. Additionally, the lightweight and compact nature of LDS makes them ideal for space applications, where weight and volume are critical constraints. By utilizing LDS, we can unlock the full potential of space exploration, pushing the boundaries of human knowledge and expanding our understanding of the universe. 8 Conclusions The study summarizes the recent progress to comprehensively explore the potential of LDS for future applications. The study explores the potential applications of LDS in fields, including portable and wearable electronics, IoT devices, renewable energy systems, electric vehicles, and smart grid applications. The efficiency of absorption of light and conversion of energy in a LDS is influenced by several factors, including the bandgap of the SCN material, the use of efficient light intensity, surface area, optimization of the structure of electrodes, electrode selection, charge separation efficiency, etc. Furthermore, the efficiency has increased and new generation gadgets that look good for use in real life have been developed. The possibility for commercialisation is likely to be studied more in the coming years, along with the scientific study and growth of LDS. The increase in efficiency and their commercialization is possible by using optimized layers of material which enable higher photovoltaic conversion having lower resistivity on integrating the energy conversion and storage module efficiently. In order to achieve high-performance LDS and further enhance their practicality, advanced in situ characterization, design of new noble photoactive and photo-induced materials and development of solid electrolytes are suggested for the future development of LDS. Moreover, the integration of PV and SCs all in one device should be realized using hybrid materials (graphene and MXene) such that the electrical, surface, electrochemical and optical characteristics of electrode materials, and their structural defect, affect LDS. Stimulating defects and a high number of working areas in the material that serves as the host layers, as well as scientific research and development of LDS, may improve LDS performance. The point defects in the visible to near-infrared spectrum decrease the band gap, the optical response in this range ensures a greater separation of these photogenerated electron-hole pairs. The electrical properties of the host material can be enhanced due to intrinsic and extrinsic defects that act as functional sites capable of adsorbing guest ions due to decrease in the activation energy of electrochemically active species. Thus, the integration of smart, portable, miniaturized and wearable PV and SCs for efficient photo-electron generation and storage all in one device promote their use in future technologies. coredata.dc:description: Photo-assisted energy harvesting plays a crucial role in present research and future scenario in the field of technology advancements towards efficient energy utilization. Modern world sees an opportunity in developing such technologies which are self-powered, self-driven and self-healing that can be utilized in the fields including portable, wearable electronics, internet of things (IOT) devices, electric vehicles, space applications, renewable energy systems, and smart grid applications. The present review gives an insight to the aspects in the present and future developmental goals in the field of light driven supercapacitors (LDS). Such systems comprise of active components viz. layer material selection in the solar cell and supercapacitors. A comprehensive study to achieve high absorption, power/energy density and efficient storage of absorbed energy has been discussed. The major factors for device design and mechanism adopted for efficient photo conversion and their subsequent storage as LDS depends on efficient light intensity source, surface area, optimization of the structure of electrodes, electrode selection, charge separation efficiency etc. A comprehensive analysis of the previously developed LDS with their optimized parameters has been presented. Various challenges viz. material selection, compatibility of layers, lower photovoltaic conversion and increased resistivity on integrating the energy conversion and storage module has also been discussed. In order to achieve high-performance LDS and to enhance their practicality various steps are suggested for the future development of LDS at industry and commercial scale.
